<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the financial assets and liabilities subject to offsetting or similar arrangements, each
	agreement between the Company and the counterparty allows for net settlement of the relevant financial assets and liabilities when both elect to settle on a net basis. In the absence of such an election, financial assets and liabilities will be
	settled on a gross basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Fair value
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The fair value of cash and cash equivalents, trade receivables, unbilled revenues, trade payables, current financial
	liabilities and borrowings approximate their carrying amount largely due to the short-term nature of these instruments. A substantial portion of the Company&#146;s long-term debt has been contracted at floating rates of interest, which are reset at
	short intervals. Accordingly, the carrying value of such long-term debt approximates fair value. Further, finance lease receivables that are overdue are periodically evaluated based on individual credit worthiness of customers. Based on this
	evaluation, the Company records allowance for estimated losses on these receivables. As of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, the carrying value of such receivables, net of allowances approximates the fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	133
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage136"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Investments in liquid and short-term mutual funds, which are classified as
	available-for-sale are measured using quoted market prices at the reporting date multiplied by the quantity held.&nbsp;Fair value of investments in certificate of deposits, classified as available for sale is determined using observable market
	inputs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The fair value of derivative financial instruments is determined based on observable market inputs including
	currency spot and forward rates, yield curves, currency volatility etc.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Fair value hierarchy
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Level 1 &#150;
</B>
	Quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Level 2 &#150;
</B>
	Inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability,
	either directly (i.e. as prices) or indirectly (i.e. derived from prices).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Level 3 &#150;
</B>
	Inputs for the assets or
	liabilities that are not based on observable market data (unobservable inputs)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table presents fair value
	hierarchy of assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following methods and assumptions were used to estimate the fair value of the level 2
	financial instruments included in the above table:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Derivative instruments (assets and liabilities): The Company enters
	into derivative financial instruments with various counter-parties, primarily banks with investment grade credit ratings. Derivatives valued using valuation techniques with market observable inputs are mainly interest rate swaps, foreign exchange
	forward contracts and foreign exchange option contracts. The most frequently applied valuation techniques include forward pricing, swap models and Black Scholes models (for option valuation), using present value calculations. The models incorporate
	various inputs including the credit quality of counterparties, foreign exchange spot and forward rates, interest rate curves and forward rate curves of the underlying. As at March&nbsp;31, 2016, the changes in counterparty credit risk had no
	material effect on the hedge effectiveness assessment for derivatives designated in hedge relationships and other financial instruments recognized at fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Available for sale investments (Investment in certificate of deposits and commercial papers): Fair value of available-for-sale
	financial assets is derived based on the indicative quotes of price and yields prevailing in the market as on March&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Available for sale investments (Investment in liquid and short-term mutual funds): Fair valuation is derived based on Net
	Asset value published by the respective mutual fund houses.
</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	134
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Derivatives assets and liabilities:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company is exposed to foreign currency fluctuations on foreign currency assets / liabilities, forecasted cash flows
	denominated in foreign currency and net investment in foreign operations. The Company follows established risk management policies, including the use of derivatives to hedge foreign currency assets / liabilities, foreign currency forecasted cash
	flows and net investment in foreign operations. The counter party in these derivative instruments is a bank and the Company considers the risks of non-performance by the counterparty as not material.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table presents the aggregate contracted principal amounts of the Company&#146;s derivative contracts
	outstanding:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The related hedge transactions for balance in cash flow hedging reserve as of March&nbsp;31,
	2016 are expected to occur and be reclassified to the statement of income over a period of 4 years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As at March&nbsp;31,
	2015 and 2016, there were no significant gains or losses on derivative transactions or portions thereof that have become ineffective as hedges, or associated with an underlying exposure that did not occur.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

</P>
<A NAME="eolPage139"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Sale of financial assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	From time to time, in the normal course of business, the Company transfers accounts receivables, unbilled revenues, net
	investment in finance lease receivables (financials assets) to banks. Under the terms of the arrangements, the Company surrenders control over the financial assets and transfer is without recourse. Accordingly, such transfers are recorded as sale of
	financial assets. Gains and losses on sale of financial assets without recourse are recorded at the time of sale based on the carrying value of the financial assets and fair value of servicing liability.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In certain cases, transfer of financial assets may be with recourse. Under arrangements with recourse, the Company is
	obligated to repurchase the uncollected financial assets, subject to limits specified in the agreement with the banks. These are reflected as part of loans and borrowings in the statement of financial position. The incremental impact of such
	transaction on our cash flow and liquidity for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016 is not material.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Financial risk management
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	General
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Market
	risk is the risk of loss of future earnings, to fair values or to future cash flows that may result from a change in the price of a financial instrument. The value of a financial instrument may change as a result of changes in the interest rates,
	foreign currency exchange rates and other market changes that affect market risk sensitive instruments. Market risk is attributable to all market risk sensitive financial instruments including investments, foreign currency receivables, payables and
	loans and borrowings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s exposure to market risk is a function of investment and borrowing activities and
	revenue generating activities in foreign currency. The objective of market risk management is to avoid excessive exposure of the Company&#146;s earnings and equity to losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Risk Management Procedures
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company manages market risk through a corporate treasury department, which evaluates and exercises independent control over
	the entire process of market risk management. The corporate treasury department recommends risk management objectives and policies, which are approved by senior management and Audit Committee. The activities of this department include management of
	cash resources, implementing hedging strategies for foreign currency exposures, borrowing strategies, and ensuring compliance with market risk limits and policies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Foreign currency risk
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company operates internationally and a major portion of its business is transacted in several currencies. Consequently, the
	Company is exposed to foreign exchange risk through receiving payment for sales and services in the United States and elsewhere, and making purchases from overseas suppliers in various foreign currencies. The exchange rate risk primarily arises from
	foreign exchange revenue, receivables, cash balances, forecasted cash flows, payables and foreign currency loans and borrowings. A significant portion of the Company&#146;s revenue is in the U.S.&nbsp;Dollar, the United Kingdom Pound&nbsp;Sterling,
	the Euro, the Canadian Dollar and the Australian Dollar, while a large portion of costs are in Indian rupees. The exchange rate between the rupee and these currencies has fluctuated significantly in recent years and may continue to fluctuate in the
	future. Appreciation of the rupee against these currencies can adversely affect the Company&#146;s results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company evaluates exchange rate exposure arising from these transactions and enters into foreign currency derivative
	instruments to mitigate such exposure. The Company follows established risk management policies, including the use of derivatives like foreign exchange forward/option contracts to hedge forecasted cash flows denominated in foreign currency.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has designated certain derivative instruments as cash flow hedges to mitigate the foreign exchange exposure of
	forecasted highly probable cash flows. The Company has also designated foreign currency borrowings as hedge against respective net investments in foreign operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016 respectively, a
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1 increase/decrease in the spot exchange rate of the Indian rupee with the U.S. dollar would result in approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,495 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,398 decrease/increase in the fair value of foreign currency dollar denominated derivative instruments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	137
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	#
</SUP>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Other currencies reflect currencies such as Singapore Dollars, Saudi Arabian Riyals etc.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016 respectively, every 1% increase/decrease of the respective foreign
	currencies compared to functional currency of the Company would impact result from operating activities by approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	318 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	343 respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Interest rate risk
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Interest rate risk primarily arises from floating rate borrowing, including various revolving and other lines of credit. The
	Company&#146;s investments are primarily in short-term investments, which do not expose it to significant interest rate risk. The Company manages its net exposure to interest rate risk relating to borrowings by entering into interest rate swap
	agreements, which allows it to exchange periodic payments based on a notional amount and agreed upon fixed and floating interest rates. As of March&nbsp;31, 2016, substantially all of the Company&#146;s borrowings were subject to floating interest
	rates, which reset at short intervals. If interest rates were to increase by 100 bps from March&nbsp;31, 2016, additional net annual interest expense on floating rate borrowing would amount to approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,102.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Credit risk
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Credit risk arises from the possibility that customers may not be able to settle their obligations as agreed. To manage this,
	the Company periodically assesses the financial reliability of customers, taking into account the financial condition, current economic trends, analysis of historical bad debts and ageing of accounts receivable. Individual risk limits are set
	accordingly. No single customer accounted for more than 10% of the accounts receivable as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, respectively and revenues for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively. There is no significant
	concentration of credit risk.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Financial assets that are neither past due nor impaired
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Cash and cash equivalents, available-for-sale financial assets, investment in certificates of deposits and interest bearing
	deposits with corporates are neither past due nor impaired. Cash and cash equivalents with banks and interest-bearing deposits are placed with corporate, which have high credit-ratings assigned by international and domestic credit-rating agencies.
	Available-for-sale financial assets substantially include investment in liquid mutual fund units. Certificates of deposit represent funds deposited with banks or other financial institutions for a specified time period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	138
</P>

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Financial assets that are past due but not impaired
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	There is no other class of financial assets that is past due but not impaired except for receivables of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	5,510 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	7,305 as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, respectively. Of the total receivables,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	67,997 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	74,200 as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, respectively, were neither past due nor impaired. The Company&#146;s credit period generally ranges from 45-60 days from invoicing date. The aging analysis of the receivables
	has been considered from the date the invoice falls due. The age wise break up of receivables, net of allowances that are past due, is given below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Counterparty risk
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Counterparty risk encompasses issuer risk on marketable securities, settlement risk on derivative and money market contracts
	and credit risk on cash and time deposits. Issuer risk is minimized by only buying securities which are at least AA rated in India based on Indian rating agencies. Settlement and credit risk is reduced by the policy of entering into transactions
	with counterparties that are usually banks or financial institutions with acceptable credit ratings. Exposure to these risks are closely monitored and maintained within predetermined parameters. There are limits on credit exposure to any financial
	institution. The limits are regularly assessed and determined based upon credit analysis including financial statements and capital adequacy ratio reviews.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Liquidity risk
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Liquidity
	risk is defined as the risk that the Company will not be able to settle or meet its obligations on time or at a reasonable price. The Company&#146;s corporate treasury department is responsible for liquidity and funding as well as settlement
	management. In addition, processes and policies related to such risks are overseen by senior management. Management monitors the Company&#146;s net liquidity position through rolling forecasts on the basis of expected cash flows. As of
	March&nbsp;31, 2016, cash and cash equivalents are held with major banks and financial institutions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The table below
	provides details regarding the remaining contractual maturities of significant financial liabilities at the reporting date. The amounts include estimated interest payments and exclude the impact of netting agreements, if any.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

</EFX_CASH_FLOW>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Income tax expense consists of the following:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	140

<A NAME="eolPage143"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Income tax expenses are net of reversal of provisions recorded in earlier
	periods, amounting to
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,244,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	891 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,337 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The
	reconciliation between the provision of income tax and amounts computed by applying the Indian statutory income tax rate to profit before taxes is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	*
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Includes deferred tax asset recognised on carry forward losses pertaining to business combinations.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Deferred taxes on unrealized foreign exchange gain / loss relating to cash flow hedges, fair value
	movements in available for sale of investments and actuarial gains/losses on defined benefit plans are recognized in other comprehensive income and presented within equity in the cash flow hedging reserve. Deferred tax liability on the intangible
	assets identified and carry forward losses on acquisitions is recorded by an adjustment to goodwill. Other than these, the change in deferred tax assets and liabilities is primarily recorded in the statement of income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	141
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage144"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company considers the
	extent to which it is probable that the deferred tax asset will be realized. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable profits during the periods in which those temporary differences and tax
	loss carry-forwards become deductible. The Company considers the expected reversal of deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income and tax planning strategies in making this assessment. Based on this, the Company believes that it is
	probable that the Company will realize the benefits of these deductible differences. The amount of deferred tax asset considered realizable, however, could be reduced in the near term if the estimates of future taxable income during the
	carry-forward period are reduced.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Deferred tax asset amounting to
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,858 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,782 as at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, respectively in respect of unused tax losses have not been recognized by the Company. The tax loss carry-forwards of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	6,509 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	6,679 as at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and March&nbsp;31, 2016, respectively, relates to certain subsidiaries on which deferred tax asset has not been recognized by the Company, because there is a lack of reasonable certainty
	that these subsidiaries may generate future taxable profits. Approximately,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	4,971 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;6,117 as at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and March&nbsp;31, 2016, respectively, of these tax loss carry-forwards is not currently subject to expiration dates. The remaining tax loss carry-forwards of approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,538 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	562 as at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and March&nbsp;31, 2016, respectively, expires in various years through fiscal 2036.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has recognized deferred tax assets of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	3,589 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	5,976 in respect of carry forward losses of its various subsidiaries as at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016. Management&#146;s projections of future taxable income and tax planning strategies support the assumption that it
	is probable that sufficient taxable income will be available to utilize these deferred tax assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Pursuant to the
	changes in the Indian income tax laws, Minimum Alternate Tax (MAT) has been extended to income in respect of which deduction is claimed under Section&nbsp;10A, 10B and 10AA of the Income Tax Act, 1961; consequently, the Company has calculated its
	tax liability for current domestic taxes after considering MAT. The excess tax paid under MAT provisions over and above normal tax liability can be carried forward and set-off against future tax liabilities computed under normal tax provisions. The
	Company was required to pay MAT and accordingly, a deferred tax asset of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,844 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,457 has been recognized in the statement of financial position as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016 respectively, which can be carried forward for a period of ten years from the year of recognition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	A substantial portion of the profits of the Company&#146;s India operations are exempt from Indian income taxes being profits
	attributable to export operations and profits from undertakings situated in Software Technology, Hardware Technology Parks and Export Oriented units. Under the tax holiday, the taxpayer can utilize an exemption from income taxes for a period of any
	ten consecutive years. The tax holidays on all facilities under Software Technology, Hardware Technology Parks and Export oriented units has expired on March&nbsp;31, 2011. Additionally, under the Special Economic Zone Act, 2005 scheme, units in
	designated special economic zones providing service on or after April&nbsp;1, 2005 will be eligible for a deduction of 100 percent of profits or gains derived from the export of services for the first five years from commencement of provision of
	services and 50 percent of such profits and gains for a further five years. Certain tax benefits are also available for a further five years subject to the unit meeting defined conditions. Profits from certain other undertakings are also eligible
	for preferential tax treatment. The tax holiday period being currently available to the Company expires in various years through fiscal 2029. The expiration period of tax holiday for each unit within a SEZ is determined based on the number of years
	that have lapsed following year of commencement of production by that unit. The impact of tax holidays has resulted in a decrease of current tax expense of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	11,043,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	11,412 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	10,212 for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 respectively, compared to the effective tax amounts that we estimate we would have been required to pay if these incentives had not been available. The per
	share effect of these tax incentives for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 was
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	4.50,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	4.65 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	4.16 respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Deferred income tax liabilities are recognized for all taxable temporary
	differences except in respect of taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries where the timing of the reversal of the temporary difference can be controlled and it is probable that the temporary difference will not
	reverse in the foreseeable future. Accordingly, deferred income tax liabilities on cumulative earnings of subsidiaries amounting to
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	26,313 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	33,920 as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, respectively has not been recognized. Further, it is not practicable to estimate the amount of the unrecognized deferred tax liabilities for these undistributed earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company is subject to U.S. tax on income attributable to its permanent establishment in the United States due to operation
	of the U.S. branch. In addition, the Company is subject to a 15% branch profit tax in the United States on the &#147;dividend equivalent amount&#148; as that term is defined under U.S. tax law. The Company has not triggered the branch profit tax
	until year ended March&nbsp;31, 2016. The Company intends to maintain the current level of net assets in the United States commensurate with its operation and consistent with its business plan. The Company does not intend to repatriate out of the
	United States any portion of its current profits. Accordingly, the Company did not record current and deferred tax provision for branch profit tax.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	142
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage145"></A>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	18. Dividends and Buy Back of equity shares
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company declares and pays dividends in Indian rupees. According to the Companies Act, 2013 any dividend should be declared
	out of accumulated distributable profits. A company may, before the declaration of any dividend, transfer a percentage of its profits for that financial year as it may consider appropriate to the reserves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The cash dividends paid per equity share were
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	8,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	10 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	12 during the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively, including an interim dividend of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	3,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	5 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	5 for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Board of Directors in their
	meeting on April&nbsp;20, 2016 proposed a final dividend of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1 (U.S.$ 0.02)&nbsp;per equity share and ADS. The proposal is subject to the approval of shareholders at the ensuing Annual General Meeting of the shareholders, and if approved, would result in a cash outflow of
	approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	2,974, including corporate dividend tax thereon. The proposed dividend has not been included as a liability in these consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On April&nbsp;20, 2016, the Board of Directors approved a buyback proposal for purchase by the Company of up to
	40&nbsp;million shares of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	2 each (representing 1.62% of total equity capital) from the shareholders of the Company on a proportionate basis by way of a tender offer at a price of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	625&nbsp;per equity share for an aggregate amount not exceeding
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	25,000&nbsp;million in accordance with the provisions of the Companies Act, 2013 and the SEBI (Buy Back of Securities) Regulations, 1998.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	19. Additional capital disclosures
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The key objective of the Company&#146;s capital management is to ensure that it maintains a stable capital structure with the
	focus on total equity to uphold investor, creditor, and customer confidence and to ensure future development of its business. The Company focused on keeping strong total equity base to ensure independence, security, as well as a high financial
	flexibility for potential future borrowings, if required without impacting the risk profile of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The
	Company&#146;s goal is to continue to be able to return excess liquidity to shareholders by continuing to distribute annual dividends in future periods. The Company has distributed an interim dividend of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	5&nbsp;per equity share during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2016. The Board of Directors in their meeting on April&nbsp;20, 2016 proposed a final dividend of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1 (U.S. $ 0.02)&nbsp;per equity share and ADS. The proposal is subject to the approval of shareholders. Further, the board of directors has approved a buy back proposal for purchase of 40&nbsp;million equity shares
	through a tender offer at a price of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	625&nbsp;per equity share. The amount of future dividends will be balanced with efforts to continue to maintain an adequate liquidity status.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The capital structure as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016 was as follows:
</P>
</EFX_NOTES_TO_FINANCIAL_STATEMENT>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	Loans and borrowings represented 16% and 21&nbsp;% of total capital as of March&nbsp;31, 2015
	and 2016, respectively. The Company is not subject to any externally imposed capital requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	20. Revenues
</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	24. Earnings per equity share
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	A reconciliation of profit for the year and equity shares used in the computation of basic and diluted
	earnings per equity share is set out below:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Basic:
</I>
	Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing the profit
	attributable to equity shareholders of the Company by the weighted average number of equity shares outstanding during the period, excluding equity shares purchased by the Company and held as treasury shares. Equity shares held by controlled Wipro
	Equity Reward Trust (&#147;WERT&#148;) and Wipro Inc Benefit Trust (&#147;WIBT&#148;) have been reduced from the equity shares outstanding for computing basic and diluted earnings per share. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2015, WIBT sold
	1.8&nbsp;million shares of Wipro Limited.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Diluted:
</I>
	Diluted earnings per share is calculated by adjusting the weighted average
	number of equity shares outstanding during the period for assumed conversion of all dilutive potential equity shares. Employee share options are dilutive potential equity shares for the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	144
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage147"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The calculation is performed in respect of share options to determine the number
	of shares that could have been acquired at fair value (determined as the average market price of the Company&#146;s shares during the period). The number of shares calculated as above is compared with the number of shares that would have been issued
	assuming the exercise of the share options.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	25. Employee stock incentive plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The stock compensation expense recognized for employee services received during the year ended
	March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 were
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;513,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;1,138 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;1,534 respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Wipro Equity Reward Trust (&#147;WERT&#148;)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 1984, the Company established a controlled trust called the Wipro Equity Reward Trust (&#147;WERT&#148;). In the earlier
	years, WERT purchased shares of the Company out of funds borrowed from the Company. The Company&#146;s Board Governance, Nomination and Compensation Committee recommends to WERT certain officers and key employees, to whom WERT grants shares from its
	holdings at nominal price. Such shares are then held by the employees subject to vesting conditions. The shares held by WERT are reported as a reduction in stockholders&#146; equity. WERT held 14,829,824 shares as at March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and
	2016.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_87"></A>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Employees covered under the stock option plans and restricted stock unit option plans
	(collectively &#147;stock option plans&#148;) are granted an option to purchase shares of the Company at the respective exercise prices, subject to requirement of vesting conditions (generally service conditions). These options generally vests in
	tranches over a period of 3 to 5 years from the date of grant. Upon vesting, the employees can acquire one equity share for every option. The maximum contractual term for these stock option plans is ten years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	145
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage148"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The weighted-average grant-date fair value of options granted during the year ended
	March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 was
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;676.73,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;658.12 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;699.96 for each option, respectively. The weighted average share price of options exercised during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 was
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;462.60,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;603.58 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;608.62 for each option, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	26. Employee benefits

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	a) Employee costs include:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Gratuity is applicable only to employees drawing a salary in Indian rupees and there are no
	other foreign defined benefit gratuity plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The expected return on plan assets is based on expectation of the average long term rate of
	return expected on investments of the fund during the estimated term of the obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The discount rate is based on
	the prevailing market yields of Indian government securities for the estimated term of the obligations. The estimates of future salary increases considered takes into account the inflation, seniority, promotion and other relevant factors. Attrition
	rate considered is the management&#146;s estimate, based on previous years&#146; employee turnover of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	147
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As at March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, plan assets were primarily invested in insurer
	managed funds
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has established an income tax approved irrevocable trust fund to which it regularly contributes
	to finance the liabilities of the plan. The fund&#146;s investments are managed by certain insurance companies as per the mandate provided to them by the trustees and the asset allocation is within the permissible limits prescribed in the insurance
	regulations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The expected future contribution and estimated future benefit payments from the fund are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The expected benefits are based on the same assumptions used to measure the Company&#146;s
	benefit obligations as of March&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	148
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage151"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Sensitivity for significant actuarial assumptions is computed to show the
	movement in defined benefit obligation by 0.5&nbsp;percentage.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of March&nbsp;31, 2016, every 0.5 percentage point
	increase/ (decrease) in discount rate will result in (decrease)/increase of gratuity benefit obligation by approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	(195),
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	218 respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of March&nbsp;31, 2016 every 0.5 percentage point increase/ (decrease)
	in expected rate of salary will result in increase/ (decrease) of gratuity benefit obligation by approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	180,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	(173)&nbsp;respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	c) Provident fund:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The details of fund and plan assets are given below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The plan assets have been primarily invested in government securities and corporate bonds.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	*
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	All the above direct subsidiaries are 100% held by the Company except that the Company holds 66.67% of the
	equity securities of Wipro Arabia Limited and 74% of the equity securities of Wipro Airport IT Services Limited.
</P>
</TD>

	51% of equity securities of Wipro Doha LLC are held by a local share holder. However, the beneficial interest
	in these holdings is with the Company.
</P>
</TD>

	The Company controls &#145;The Wipro SA Broad Based Ownership Scheme Trust&#146;
	and &#145;Wipro SA Broad Based Ownership Scheme SPV (RF) (PTY) LTD incorporated in South Africa.

	Effective October&nbsp;1, 2012
</P>
</TD>
</TR>

	153
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage156"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	28. Commitments and contingencies
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Operating leases:
</I>
	The Company has taken office, vehicles and IT equipment under cancellable and non-cancellable
	operating lease agreements that are renewable on a periodic basis at the option of both the lessor and the lessee. The operating lease agreements extend up to a maximum of fifteen years from their respective dates of inception and some of these
	lease agreements have price escalation clause. Rental payments under such leases were
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	4,583,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	4,727 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	5,184 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Details of
	contractual payments under non-cancelable leases are given below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Capital commitments: As at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, the Company had committed to spend
	approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,262 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;10,734 respectively, under agreements to purchase property and equipment. These amounts are net of capital advances paid in respect of these purchases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Guarantees: As at March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, performance and financial guarantees provided by banks on behalf of the
	Company to the Indian Government, customers and certain other agencies amount to approximately
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	21,234 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	25,218 respectively, as part of the bank line of credit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Contingencies and lawsuits: The
	Company is subject to legal proceedings and claims (including tax assessment orders/ penalty notices) which have arisen in the ordinary course of its business. Some of the claims involve complex issues and it is not possible to make a reasonable
	estimate of the expected financial effect, if any, that will result from ultimate resolution of such proceedings. However, the resolution of these legal proceedings is not likely to have a material and adverse effect on the results of operations or
	the financial position of the Company. The significant of such matters are discussed below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In March 2004, the Company
	received a tax demand for year ended March&nbsp;31, 2001 arising primarily on account of denial of deduction under section 10A of the Income Tax Act, 1961 (Act) in respect of profit earned by the Company&#146;s undertaking in Software Technology
	Park at Bangalore. The same issue was repeated in the successive assessments for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2002 to March&nbsp;31, 2011 and the aggregate demand is
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;47,583 (including interest of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;13,832). The appeals filed against the said demand before the Appellate authorities have been allowed in favor of the Company by the second appellate authority for the years up to March&nbsp;31, 2007. Further
	appeals have been filed by the Income tax authorities before the Hon&#146;ble High Court. The Hon&#146;ble High Court has heard and disposed-off majority of the issues in favor of the Company up to years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On similar issues for years up to March&nbsp;31, 2000, the Hon&#146;ble High Court of Karnataka has upheld the claim of the
	Company under section 10A of the Act. For the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2008 and March&nbsp;31, 2009, the appeals are pending before Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (Tribunal). For years ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 and March&nbsp;31, 2011, the Dispute
	Resolution Panel (DRP) allowed the claim of the Company under section 10A of the Act. The Income tax authorities have filed an appeal before the Tribunal.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For year ended March&nbsp;31, 2012, the Company received the draft assessment order in March 2016 with a proposed demand of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;4,241 (including interest of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	1,376), arising primarily on account of section 10AA issues with respect to exclusion from Export Turnover. Company has filed an objection before DRP within the prescribed timelines.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Considering the facts and nature of disallowance and the order of the appellate authority / Hon&#146;ble High Court of
	Karnataka upholding the claims of the Company for earlier years, the Company believes that the final outcome of the above disputes should be in favor of the Company and there should not be any material adverse impact on the financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Contingent liability in respect of disputed demands for excise duty, custom duty, sales tax and other matters amounts
	to
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	&nbsp;2,560 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	2,654 as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2016, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	154
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D185139D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	29. Segment Information
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company is organized by the following operating segments: IT Services and IT Products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	IT Services:
</B>
	The IT Services segment primarily consists of IT Service offerings to customers organized by industry
	verticals as follows: Banking, Financial Services and Insurance (BFSI), Healthcare and Life Sciences (HLS), Retail, Consumer, Transport and Government (RCTG), Energy, Natural Resources and Utilities (ENU), Manufacturing (MFG), Global Media and
	Telecom (GMT). It also includes Others which comprises dividend income and gains or losses (net) relating to strategic investments, which are presented within &#147;Finance and other income&#148; in the statement of Income. Key service offering to
	customers includes software application development and maintenance, research and development services for hardware and software design, business application services, analytics, digital, consulting, infrastructure outsourcing services and business
	process services.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	IT Products
</B>
	: The Company is a value added reseller of desktops, servers, notebooks, storage
	products, networking solutions and packaged software for leading international brands. In certain total outsourcing contracts of the IT Services segment, the Company delivers hardware, software products and other related deliverables. During FY
	2013-14, the Company ceased the manufacturing of &#145;Wipro branded desktops, laptops and servers&#146;. Revenue relating to the above items is reported as revenue from the sale of IT Products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Chairman&nbsp;&amp; Managing Director of the Company has been identified as the Chief Operating Decision Maker (CODM) as
	defined by IFRS 8, &#147;Operating Segments.&#148; The Chairman of the Company evaluates the segments based on their revenue growth and operating income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Assets and liabilities used in the Company&#146;s business are not identified to any of the operating segments, as these are
	used interchangeably between segments. Management believes that it is currently not practicable to provide segment disclosures relating to total assets and liabilities since a meaningful segregation of the available data is onerous.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Information on operating segments for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2016 is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has four geographic segments: India, Americas, Europe and Rest of the world. The
	Americas refer to North and South America. Revenues from the geographic segments based on domicile of the customer are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	No client individually accounted for more than 10% of the revenues during the year ended
	March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Management believes that it is currently not practicable to provide disclosure of
	assets by geographical location, as meaningful segregation of the available information is onerous.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Notes:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	&#147;Reconciling items&#148; includes elimination of inter-segment transactions, dividend income/ gains/
	losses relating to strategic investments and other corporate activities.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Segment result represents operating profits of the segments and dividend income and gains or losses (net)
	relating to strategic investments, which are presented within &#147;Finance and other income&#148; in the statement of Income.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	c)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Revenues include excise duty of
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	79,
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	2 and
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/26/0001193125-16-604459_G185139DSP118.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
	Nil for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively. For the purpose of segment reporting, the segment revenues are net of excise duty. Excise duty is reported in reconciling items.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	d)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Revenue from sale of traded cloud based licenses is reported as part of IT Services revenues.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	e)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	For the purpose of segment reporting, the Company has included the impact of &#147;foreign exchange gains /
	(losses), net&#148; in revenues (which is reported as a part of operating profit in the statement of income).
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	f)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	For evaluating performance of the individual operating segments, stock compensation expense is allocated on
	the basis of straight line amortization. The differential impact of accelerated amortization of stock compensation expense over stock compensation expense allocated to the individual operating segments is reported in reconciling items.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	g)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	For evaluating the performance of the individual operating segments, amortization of customer and marketing
	related intangibles acquired through business combinations are reported in reconciling items.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	h)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	The Company generally offers multi-year payment terms in certain total outsourcing contracts. These payment
	terms primarily relate to IT hardware, software and certain transformation services in outsourcing contracts. Corporate treasury provides internal financing to the business units offering multi-year payments terms. The finance income on deferred
	consideration earned under these contracts is included in the revenue of the respective segment and is eliminated under reconciling items.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD VALIGN="TOP" NOWRAP>
	15.1
</TD>

</TD>
